**Follow me for artificial intelligence and tech news, insights, job advice, and hiring posts!**

Started in AI nearly 20 years ago. Deep background in artificial intelligence, machine learning, technology, org management, product management, cognitive science, product and user experience, startups, angel investing, and venture capital.

*****
Instagram: www.instagram.com/alliekmiller
Twitter: www.twitter.com/alliekmiller
TikTok: www.tiktok.com/@alliekmiller

For private advising sessions with Allie, you can book 30min and 60min sessions here: www.linktree.com/alliekmiller

For brand partnerships, paid speaking engagements, investor pitches, or other inquiries: hello@alliekmiller.com

I am at my maximum connections, please follow to stay connected ðŸ’ª

*****

Allie Miller is a top artificial intelligence leader, advisor, and investor.

Previously, Allie was the Global Head of Machine Learning Business Development for Startups and Venture Capital at Amazon (AWS), advising the top machine learning researchers and founders in the world.

Prior to that, Allie was the youngest-ever woman to build an artificial intelligence product at IBMâ€”spearheading product development across computer vision, conversation, data, and regulation for thousands of companies.

Outside of work, Allie is changing the game of AI. Allie has spoken about AI around the world, advises on global AI public policy, and created eight guidebooks to educate businesses on how to build successful AI projects.

Allie was named as AIconicâ€™s 2019 "AI Innovator of the Year", LinkedIn Top Voice for Technology and AI 2019 & 2020 & 2021, Award Magazineâ€™s Top 50 Women in Tech and Top 100 Global Thought Leaders, Chief in Techâ€™s Top 100 Women in Tech to Watch in 2022, ReadWriteâ€™s Top 20 AI Speakers in the World, MKAIâ€™s Top 20 AI Mavericks, Data Salonâ€™s Top 25 Data Science influencers in the world, and Neptuneâ€™s Top 20 AI Influencers. Allie is also the co-founder of Girls of the Future, a national ambassador for the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), an ambassador for the 10,000-person organization Advancing Women in Product, an angel investor in machine learning startups, and has won the Grand Prize in three national innovation competitions.

Allie holds a double-major MBA from The Wharton School and a BA in Cognitive Science (coding a three-year ML study and studying Computer Science, Linguistics, Psychology) from Dartmouth College.

_____________________________________
My posts are my own and do not reflect the opinions of my current, past, or future employers.

posts.postDescription:
Honey, I compacted the Al model.

Researchers at Microsoft were able to train an LLM with model weights stored in a format that is a heck of a lot smaller than current LLMs while still achieving the same quality.

They built on the BitNet work from MSFT last year that represented parameters in binary (aka Os and 1s) instead of FP and added a third option (aka -1, 0, 1) for a little more detail...without losing any speed...and still gaining some performance. Wow.

"The 1.58-bit LLM defines a new scaling law and recipe for training new generations of LLMs that are both high-performance and cost-effective," says the paper.

Their 3B model uses 3.5x less memory while running 2.7x faster than an equivalent Llama model.

So what does this mean? Model size and cost have been barriers to entry for LLMs, but we may see models run more efficiently on cheaper GPUs or make extremely scaled LLMs without increasing the cost or complexity of hosting.

This may also reduce hardware demands and energy consumption, so we may be seeing a more sustainable future for Al.

*I'm not an eng, I read these for fun/my job, ping an MLE with questions
